issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: add a property in the partition to figure out if stats are accurate

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

fields.summary: numRows cannot be set by user

comments.body: Minimal patch just to see what tests fail.

ATTACHMENT ID: 12678088 - PreCommit-HIVE-TRUNK-Build

Issue here is that we want to invalidate these stats if this an alter statement like alter table drop partition. Currently, this flag is used to signal metastore to let through changes in table properties after stats task (or with autogather).  I will look into this more in detail sometime later.
[~ashutoshc] it looks we need to pass the fact that we are not adding or deleting data from {{HiveAlterHandler}} to {{MetastoreUtils}}. Is that correct? If so, I can do that.
yeah, thats correct.  If you put up a patch, happy to review it.

Looks like we'd have to somehow plumb the operation from the {{DDLTask}} to the {{HiveAlterTableHandler}} as all {{HiveAlterTableHandler}} get's is a new copy of the table, not the operation.

Attached is my patch before I saw that this issue.

Hi [~ashutoshc] Could you help me know what kind of ALTER operations can cause to invalidate these stats?

I tried running alter drop partitions while debugging, but the {{updateUnpartitionedTableStatsFast}} is not called.

This really depends on *type* of alter command which one is performing. Some alter command may invalidate stats, others may not. Problem is currently IIRC HiveAlterTableHandler, doesnt pay any attention to type of alter statement, it blindly tries to invalidate, where it actually should look at the context.
Also, at the very least we need to test this with documented alter statements on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+DDL#LanguageManualDDL-AlterTable/Partition/Column

just as an example in case of alter table touch we may not need to invalidate, but for alter table replace columns we may need to. HiveAlterTableHandler doesnt pay attention to this context yet, tries to be conservative and invalidate in all cases.
